displaytitle: Academic study of adolescent boy, seen from behind
creditline: Museum purchase, John Maclean Magie, Class of 1892, and Gertrude Magie Fund

titles.title: Academic study of adolescent boy, seen from behind

makers.displaymaker: Horace Vernet, 1789–1863; born and died Paris, France

texts.textentryhtml: Heim, London (by 1978–81; sold to Princeton University Art Museum).

The model for this life study was posed to recall sculptures of the god Apollo, who in antiquity was often given a youthful, even androgynous, form. Vernet’s image is hardly idealized or historicizing, however. The artist shows the model’s dirty fingernails and includes the props—stacked boxes and an old, frayed pillow—used to help the young man hold his classical stance.

This painting reflects the academic training required of students at the École des Beaux-Arts in nineteenth-century Paris. First, they learned to draw using prints and other drawings as their guides. Then, they graduated to drawing after sculpture, often using ancient works or plaster casts as models; finally, they drew or painted from live models.

bibliography.boilertext: Allen Rosenbaum and Francis F. Jones, Selections from The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1986)
bibliography.citation: Allen Rosenbaum and Francis F. Jones, Selections from The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1986), p. 100 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: Nina Maria Athanassoglou-Kallmyer, "Horace Vernet's "Academic Study of an Adolescent Boy" and the artist's student years," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 45, no. 2 (1986): p. 16–24.
bibliography.citation: Nina Maria Athanassoglou-Kallmyer, "Horace Vernet's "Academic Study of an Adolescent Boy" and the artist's student years," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 45, no. 2 (1986): p. 16–24., p. 18, fig. 1
